news.headline: European car sales rise 4.9% in October, ACEA says
news.summary: STORY: New car sales in Europe rose 4.9% in October as electric cars outpaced petrol and diesel registrations.Data from the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association showed on Tuesday (November 25) that sales in the EU, Britain and the European Free Trade Association rose to over a million cars.Its largest markets including Germany and Britain added more new cars than last year.The European car industry has taken a series of hits this year.They include Donald Trump's trade tariffs, a slowdown in the Chinese market.And a slower-than-expected transition to electric vehicles.There have also been recent worries about a potential chip supply chain crisis surrounding Dutch chipmaker Nexperia.Registrations at Volkswagen, Stellantis, rose year-on-year by 6.5% and 4.6% respectively, while Renault went up more than a tenth.Tesla's sales meanwhile dropped almost by half from a year ago.While BYD's sales jumped a near 207%.And while electrics and hybrids saw a boost, all major markets saw drops in their petrol and diesel registrations.

news.headline: Record US Black Friday crowds to find fewer bargains amid high prices
news.summary: STORY: Black Friday crowds are expected to be bigger than ever this year, but their spending may not keep pace.Retailers strained by tariffs are rolling out fewer deals this year, making true bargains harder to find for shoppers. The National Retail Federation projects nearly 187 million people will shop in the five-day stretch from Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday. That would be the most ever and up from about 183 million last year.Retailers have launched early promotions to lock in sales.Walmart’s began on November 14 and will run in three phases through December 1, with Walmart+ members getting early access.Amazon started its Black Friday deals week on Thursday, while Macy's has opened a dedicated Black Friday portal.Sales in stores and online in November and December are forecast to top $1 trillion for the first time, according to the National Retail Federation.It expects sales growth of about 4% but that would be down from the nearly 5% rise in sales in 2024. Spending per person is seen falling slightly and a National Retail Federation poll shows that more consumers than last year say they will wait for Thanksgiving weekend deals.Eric Matisoff, an Analytics & Data Science Evangelist at Adobe who works with retailers, says consumers are also looking to pay less of the purchase price up front.“One big increase for growth this year that we're seeing is an increase in usage of buy now, pay later. So we're expecting $2 billion worth of purchases to be made using that type of technology, which shows that consumers are still really excited to make purchases and get value out of the discounts that we're seeing. However, they're looking to figure out ways to make the most of their money and stretch it.”One analyst who tracks consumer pricing tells Reuters that knowing when the best prices will appear is hard to determine because retailers have started promotions so early this year that those deals may not be available for Black Friday or the items could be out of stock.

news.headline: Big Tech starts complying with Australia's teen social media ban
news.summary: STORY: Australian teenagers are set to lose their social media accounts, with a ban on young users set to kick in from December 10. Over the coming days, online platforms like TikTok, Snapchat, Meta and Instagram will notify more than a million teen account holders in the country. Users under the age of 16 must choose an option: Download data, freeze their profiles, or lose everything under the world-first ban on kids using social media.Based on information from insiders, the big platforms plan to deactivate accounts for users under the age of 16.Australia's other 20 million social media users should face no big changes.The move puts the nation out front in shielding young people from online risks.Earlier this year, platforms had warned of total chaos, fearing that they could lose users and face $32 million fines for breaking the rules.They said required age checks would mean constant logins, invade privacy and often be wrong or easy to dodge.But now, firms will use existing software that guesses ages from user habits, instead of asking for birth dates all the time.They will generally only push people to special age-check apps if someone complains about being blocked by mistake.The setup might hit snags at first.Age-check apps which are being deployed at scale for the first time can make mistakes.La Trobe University AI professor Daswin De Silva explains:"One of the challenges with age verification also is this band between 15, 16, 17, how do you distinguish 15 from 16 to 17. So a lot of the technological methods of age verification will fail in that narrow band and there might be false positives where certain individuals who are over 16, slightly over 16 will be banned from these platforms because their content was classified as relevant to under an 16 sort of target demographic.""It's probably going to be service distortion, service failure for a couple of days or weeks maybe until the platforms figure this out, and we'll see a lot of articles on media and maybe on social media itself of false positives."Meta, Snapchat, TikTok and Google declined to comment.The law states that such platforms must take "reasonable steps" to block minors.If the rollout goes smoothly, it could guide the world in cutting kids' exposure to harms like bullying or weight issues from screens.The UK and France added age gates for porn earlier this year. Then in November, Denmark said it would ban under-15s from social media.

news.headline: S&P Dow Jones Indices Announces Changes to the S&P/TSX 60 Index and S&P/TSX Composite Index
news.summary: The shareholders of Gildan Activewear Inc. (TSX: GIL) (NYSE: GIL) and Hanesbrands Inc (NYSE: HBI) have agreed to the terms of a Plan of Arrangement resulting in the combination of the two companies. Each share of Hanesbrand will be exchanged for US$ 0.80 in cash and 0.102 shares of Gildan Activewear for each Hanesbrand share held.

news.headline: S&P Global Launches WSO Compliance Insights to Streamline Credit Risk Management
news.summary: S&P Global (NYSE: SPGI) today announced the launch of WSO Compliance Insights, a comprehensive compliance management solution designed to enhance credit risk management for private credit and CLO managers. This application, available through S&P Global Market Intelligence, utilizes real-time data streaming, enabling users to streamline compliance processes, eliminate end-of-day batch processing and improve decision-making capabilities.
